title: A Comparative Analysis of Generalised Echo and Interference Cancelling and Extended Multichannel Wiener Filtering for Combined Noise Reduction and Acoustic Echo Cancellation
author: Arnout Roebben (KU Leuven), Toon van Waterschoot (KU Leuven), Marc Moonen (KU Leuven), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores techniques related to acoustic echo cancellation (AEC) and noise reduction (NR), which aligns with Dr. Liu's interests in audio and speech processing, particularly in enhancing audio quality.
background: This study investigates methods to eliminate unwanted noise and echo from audio recordings in real-time scenarios, improving overall audio quality.
contribution: The paper introduces a comparison between two algorithms, Generalised Echo and Interference Canceller (GEIC) and Extended Multichannel Wiener Filter (MWFext), to improve both echo cancellation and noise reduction.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous algorithms examined only linear echo paths and relied on voice activity detectors (VADs), which may introduce errors in detection.
technical_comparison.novelty: This study extends existing analyses by incorporating general nonlinear echo paths and addressing the impact of VAD errors on each algorithm, thus providing a more comprehensive evaluation.

key_innovation: The integration of nonlinear echo modeling and VAD error effects enhances the robustness of analysis in AEC and NR algorithms, making the findings more applicable to real-world scenarios.
real_world_impact: Improvements in acoustic signal processing can lead to better communication quality in settings such as teleconferencing and hearing aids, ultimately enhancing user experiences.
limitations: No specific limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Generalised Bussgang decomposition: **Generalised Bussgang decomposition** is a method that allows for the separation of received signals into linear and residual components for better signal analysis.
new_terms.voice activity detector (VAD): **Voice activity detector** is a system that identifies the presence of human speech in audio recordings, which can be prone to errors affecting AEC and NR performance.
